Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Hurricane Irene Storm Surge Sedimentation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This RAPID project will study storm surge sediments deposited by Hurricane Irene in coastal marshes along the east coast of the United States. Questions to be addressed by the study are:
1. What is the magnitude and regional distribution of Hurricane Irene storm surge sedimentation?
2. How does the orientation of the hurricane track in relation to the coastline affect storm surge
sedimentation?
3. What is the contribution of Hurricane Irene to long-term sedimentation in coastal marshes?
4. Are the storm surge deposits preserved in marshes?
Methods to be used include field surveys of the thickness, inland penetration, volume, mass, spatial distribution and structures of Hurricane Irene?s storm surge deposit. In addition, samples will be collected to determine background sedimentation rates against which to compare the hurricane sedimentation and thus its overall role in coastal marsh evolution.

This project aims to improve our understanding of how hurricanes contribute to the formation of coastal marshes. The relative importance of such high-magnitude events in the overall evolution of these coastal landscape features remains the subject of debate. The project will also contribute to the field of paleotempestology, which provides assessments of the recurrence interval of hurricane strikes and associated hurricane risk. By providing information on the characteristics of a fresh hurricane deposit, the project will help constrain interpretations of past events that are preserved in the geologic record.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Little work has been done on regional distribution and magnitude of hurricane storm surge sedimentation. This study adds an additional dataset from the East Coast that can be compared to existing datasets from the Gulf Coast. Previous studies by the PI indicate that hurricanes may play a much more significant role in the formation of coastal plains than has been previously recognized. It is important to understand how hurricane deposits are incorporated into, and became part of, coastal environments, such as marshes. The project includes assessment of long-term preservation of the washover deposits based on repeat surveys conducted one to two years after landfall. This study had the following objectives:
1. What is the magnitude and regional distribution of Hurricane Irene storm surge sedimentation?
2. How does the orientation of the hurricane track in relation to the coastline affect storm surge sedimentation?
3. What is the contribution of Hurricane Irene to long-term sedimentation in coastal marshes?
4. Are the storm surge deposits preserved in marshes?

Hurricane Irene's storm surge deposits were studied on Fire Island New York, Cape Lookout, North Carolina, Cape Hatteras, North Carolina and Assateague Island, Virginia. Sedimentation was in the form of washover fans. Field work included mapping of fan, measurement of fan thickness and sampling of fan sediments for particle size, bulk density and foraminiferal content. Patrick Strong, a UNT graduate student was hired as a research assistant to help with field work and lab work. To assess long-term preservation of deposits (by comparing the original survey to the repeat survey), sites on Fire Island and on Cape Lookout were resurveyed in late 2012/early 2013.  

Study results indicate that Hurricane Irene's storm surge sedimentation occurred along a large segment of the East Coast because the track of the hurricane paralleled the coast from North Carolina to New York. However, the magnitude of sedimentation was low because Irene was a relatively weak storm at landfall and did not generate a very large storm surge. Sedimentation was restricted to isolated sandy washover fans which, in many cases, formed where there was a pre-existing breach in coastal barriers (berm or dunes).  There are significant contrasts in the style of sedimentation between the East Coast and the Gulf Coast, probably related to contrasting offshore and onshore conditions. Sedimentation on the Gulf Coast (e.g. from Hurricanes Rita and Ike) includes an extensive (~3 km inland) sheet-like deposit of fine-grained sediment (predominantly silt and clay), which most likely originates from wave erosion of shallow offshore areas and is a consequence of gentle offshore gradients in the Gulf of Mexico. Field evidence suggests this part of the storm surge sedimentation is deposited from suspension. On the east coast, following Hurricane Irene, this type of storm surge sediment was completely absent; Irene deposited only sandy washover fans from traction load and these fans extended only a short distance inland (~100 m). Possible explanations for this contrast include a lack of fine-grained deposits offshore along the east coast, a steeper offshore gradient on the east coast (putting fine grained deposits below the depth of Hurricane Irene's wave erosion) or the smaller size of Hurricane Irene compared to Hurricanes Rita and Ike. Repeat surveys of Hurricane Irene's storm surge deposits show that they are generally well-preserved; most were intact (same thickness as in original survey) and covered by vegetation. The exception was on Fire Island, NY, where Hurricane Sandy either eroded or obscured (by sedimentation) Hurricane Irene's deposits.
